docs.lead_paragraph: HE is one of the world's biggest stars. Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan has spent three decades turning an esoteric form of music -- qawwali, the singing style of Pakistan's Sufi Muslim mystics -- into an international buzzword. He has been interviewed on MTV and VH1 and collaborated with Eddie Vedder of Pearl Jam and Peter Gabriel. Joan Osborne went to Pakistan to ask for singing tips, and in Los Angeles last week, Madonna and Michael Stipe of R.E.M., in addition to the actors Stephen Dorff and Rosanna Arquette, showed up at a concert to watch Mr. Kahn sit cross-legged on the stage and let loose some of the world's most entrancing vocal pyrotechnics.

headline.main: Enchanter at the Crossroads Of Pop and Sacred

docs.abstract: Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan has spent three decades turning esoteric form of music--qawwali, the singing style of Pakistan's Sufi Muslim mystics--into international buzzword; in Pakistan, Khan remains unchallenged as greatest living qawwali singer; his music sends spectators into trances; he is now being recorded on American rock labels; photo (M)8

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Florence Joffe first went to the Wholistic Health Center in Syosset, she was suffering from asthma. At the center, Faye Schenkman, an herbalist and holistic health care practitioner, treated Mrs. Joffe, of Great Neck, with herbal formulas whose ingredients contained ephedra. ''With these natural herbs,'' said Mrs. Schenkman, ''she was able to avoid taking medications that might have had serious side effects.''

headline.main: Nassau Restricts Herbal Aids With Stimulant

docs.abstract: Use of herbs for treatment of diseases discussed; herbalists caution that, as with medicine, care must be taken with herbs; Herb Research Foundation's proposed regulatory plan for herbs described; regulation of herbs is now up to individual states; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was a typical workday for Howard C. Birndorf at Nanogen Inc., the biotechnology company he helped to found here three years ago. As he showed a visitor around, he met three new employees he had never seen before; introduced Harry Leonhardt, the general counsel hired a few days earlier from Allergan Inc.; wound through rooms of brand-new lasers, microscopes and beakers to a basketball court about to be turned into more laboratory space, and showed off an empty cubicle. ''This will be our C.F.O.'s office, when we have one,'' said Mr. Birndorf, chairman and chief executive of Nanogen, which is privately held.

headline.main: The Johnny Appleseed of a Biotechnology Forest

docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Howard C Birndorf, chmn and chief exec of Nanogen Inc, biotechnology company that he helped found three years ago; he asserts that company is going to revolutionize business of diagnosing diseases by marrying computers and biology, performing tests currently done in test tubes on surfaces of microchips; many peokple see this as mong brighter fields in diagnostics, $17.5 billion-a-year industry worldwide; Birndorf has been involved in one capacity or another in founding of six biotechnology companies; photos; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK Adults in Shelters Must Work In a significant expansion of the city's workfare program, homeless adults living with their families in city shelters will now be required to work for the city in exchange for their welfare benefits, aides to Mayor Giuliani said. The plan will take effect this fall for most of the 5,700 adults with children who live in city shelters. $(Page 1.$) Clinton's Manhattan Bash President Clinton plans to celebrate turning 50 by concentrating on one of his driving priorities -- raising campaign funds, this time through an elaborate birthday bash at Radio City Music Hall. Some of the biggest money will be raised after the Radio City show at a dinner at the Waldorf, where the ticket minimum is $10,000 per person. $(1.$) A Manhattan baker had the task of making the birthday cake for the Presidential bash. But first he had to get permission to miss class. $(9.$) Requiem for a Music Store After a lifetime of selling scores to instrumentalists, vocalists and a conductor or two -- from private-school band directors in her Upper East Side neighborhood to stick wavers from across town at Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall -- Ruth Binzer is closing the sheet-music store her father bought, her mother ran and she and her sister inherited. $(21.$) Out of Sadness, Garden Grows For more than two years after Kali Ann Poulton disappeared in a Rochester suburb, people hoped, or prayed, that she was still alive. So when people found out that Kali had been killed, all their emotions needed a place to be expressed. And so people began arriving at Gleason Estates, at the raised flower bed dedicated to Kali on the first anniversary of her abduction. $(21.$) 'Someone Who Wants to Help' Three years ago in Crown Heights, Rabbi Israel Shemtov rescued a woman who had been shot. On Monday, he talked a man out of jumping off the Brooklyn Bridge. But he has also been charged over the years with assault, rioting and just plain getting in the way. ''Why should I put my neck out?'' Rabbi Shemtov asked. ''Sometimes with a yell you can let someone feel there is someone who wants to help.'' About New York by David Gonzalez. $(21.$) Criticism Over Drugs at Dance The Morning Party, an annual gay dance that draws thousands to Fire Island Pines, raises hundreds of thousands of dollars for the Gay Men's Health Crisis. But it is widely known that drugs have become an integral part of the dance, with critics contending that Gay Men's Health Crisis is turning a blind eye to the drug use that impairs judgment and reduces inhibitions, leading to the sexual behavior that can result in transmission of the AIDS virus. $(22.$) More Surgery for Officer A police officer who was ambushed and shot in the head in Washington Heights underwent a second round of surgery. Hospital officials said his condition was deteriorating and then stabilizing from one hour to the next. The Police Department continued to search for a suspect. $(23.$) Police Report Cited in Suit In an unusual civil rights lawsuit being heard in Federal District Court in Manhattan, three current and former officers in the corruption-ridden 30th Precinct are accused of hitting and wrongly arresting a mother and her son in Harlem in 1991. To bolster the case, lawyers for the mother and son have enlisted the aid of the Mollen Commission report. $(23.$) Official May Veto Language Bill In a signal that he may veto a bill to make English the official language of Suffolk County, County Executive Robert J. Gaffney issued a statement saying that he would oppose the measure if he concluded that it singled out Hispanic people. $(24.$) REGION Witnesses Crucial to Inquiry Witnesses like Michael Russell, who saw the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, have helped shape both the technical inquiry into the cause of the crash and the F.B.I.'s hunt for clues to any possible criminal acts. $(21.$) Preliminary examination of all four engines from Flight 800 largely rule out the idea that engine failure caused the crash. $(24.$) Queens Hit by Another Jet Piece An eight-foot section of a wing flap broke off a T.W.A. plane and plunged onto a Queens street, where it left deep gashes in the roadway. The incident was the second this week in which pieces of an aircraft fell to earth in Queens. $(24.$) CONNECTICUT Rowland Nears Candidacy Bid Gov. John G. Rowland has moved closer toward declaring his candidacy for a second term, establishing a campaign committee to accept contributions. Although Mr. Rowland has not formally committed to the race, his forming a committee shows he has started to prepare for it. $(24.$)
